input:
AI principles I know at 29, I wish I had known at 24.
- Don't use AI
- Focus on problems not tech
- Spend more time on data curation
- Data quality > data quantity
- Run experiments
writing_steps:
Step 1: Purpose and Target Audience
- Purpose: Share practical, hard-earned AI principles for early-career professionals and aspiring engineers to help them avoid common mistakes.
- Target Audience: Early-career AI engineers, students, and anyone getting started in AI.

Step 2: Wireframe
[Hook]
[5 principles as bullet points + 1-2 lines context for each]
[CTA: factual, prompting specific technical input]

Step 3: Body (meat)
Lay out each principle as a direct statement, with one explanatory line for each. Stay literal and actionable.

Step 4: CTA
Ask for one specific principle readers would add (practical and focused).

Step 5: Hooks Brainstorm
A. [User's phrasing] "AI principles I know at 29, I wish I had known at 24."
B. [Problem/solution] "Most new AI engineers focus on the wrong things. Here are 5 lessons I wish I'd started with."
C. [Beginner-to-expert clarity] "The biggest mistakes I made early in AI (and what to do instead)."
D. [Numbered list] "5 real-world AI principles I wish someone had told me earlier."
E. [Trend/urgency] "Too many people jump straight into tools—here are the AI principles that actually matter."

Step 5B: Notes for each direction
A. (Captures genuine reflection; close to original)
B. (Sets up common pitfalls)
C. (Shows learning-from-failure angle)
D. (Simple, direct)
E. (Addresses growing hype and tool-obsession)

Step 5C: Strongest direction
The original phrasing is direct and personal, matching Shaw's voice. I'll use direction A, drawing on D for clarity.

Final Hook: 
AI principles I know at 29, I wish I had known at 24.

Step 6: Full Draft
AI principles I know at 29, I wish I had known at 24.

If you're early in your AI career (or even if not), these are the five things I would focus on:

- Don't use AI if you don't need it. Not every problem needs a model or automation.
- Focus on real problems, not just technology or hype.
- Spend more time on data curation. The upfront work pays off later.
- Prioritize data quality over data quantity. More examples won't fix poor labels or noise.
- Run experiments continuously instead of chasing perfect solutions on paper.

What practical principle would you add to this list?

Step 7: Style/Voice/Flow Review
- Hook is fact-based, personal without being motivational.
- Each principle is stated plainly, with actionable notes.
- CTA is single, practical, and literal. No 'or' or motivational prompt.
- No em dash (checked!).
- No business clichés or idioms.
- Cross-referenced with examples 1 and 5—tone, spacing, structure, and intent align closely.

Step 8: Final Post
